comments.text:
What's more, while we think of Castoreum as an imitation of Vanilla, 
Catstoreum is naturally occuring in the state we use it, whereas Vanilla 
extract comes from cooked, fermented, and aged seed pods that have to be 
processed in a complicated, counter-intuitive, and precise set of steps in 
order to bring out their flavor. It then follows that, given that we humans 
have been hunting beavers since the end of the Pleistocene, but have only 
been cultivating Vanilla for a few centuries, which do you think we've been 
flavoring our Cakes and Ice cream with for longer? Here's a hint, probably 
the one that our usage of pre-dates the invention of ice-cream rather than 
post-dates it. lol.

top_comment.text:
Okay I have a question. Light has no mass, right? And gravity only works 
between two objects that have mass, so how does a black hole pull light in 
if it has no mass?﻿
top_comment.author: Kaden Moss

comments.text:
You are a mammal and a dog is a mammal, that doesn't mean you are a dog. 
 You're both the same thing in that you're mammals, but still have 
different characteristics.

Light and matter are both forms of energy, but they are DIFFERENT forms and 
so do not have the same characteristics.  In this case a key differences in 
their characteristics is whether they have the property "massless" or 
"massive."
comments.author: Meg Ashley

comments.text:
+Bud Charles So if energy and mass are practically the same, why is light 
massless?
comments.author: Anduin Wrynn

comments.text:
The beavers build a dam to stop the light from flowing out of the black 
holes.
comments.author: Matthew Przeslicke

comments.text:
Energy is mass. I know that sounds weird but E=MC^2 shows how mass and 
energy can be converted into each other.
comments.author: Bud Charles

comments.text:
Because gravity bends space plane and simple.  light only appears to bend 
to an outside observer but effectively travels in a straight line to a 
local observer.   likewise light has two behaviors particle and wave.   Due 
to this it can be effected by gravity very very very minutely.  The primary 
reason light can "bend" though, is because it doesn't bend at all,  space 
does due to gravity, light just follows the straight-line path through 
curved space. If you have a trampoline you can demonstrate this easily by 
tapeing a string to it in a straight line with a flat plane.   then apply a 
mass to the trampoline doesn't really matter what just enough to make the 
trampoline curve to its weight.   you'll notice your straight line of yarn 
appears curved suddenly.                          
 oh  and for nerd-fighters everywhere with iPhones check out my new game 
its a lot of fun.   
https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/puckface/id896124365?mt=8
comments.author: Cody Peters

comments.text:
Because the source of gravity is energy, not mass. Yes, schools lie to you 
(a lot, actually). Get over it.
comments.author: masansr

comments.text:
Mohawk has the right idea for his first sentence.  At some point mass and 
energy are the same thing, and so are both affected by gravity.  It's also 
worth noting that light shining on something actually imparts a force to 
it, because photons (even without mass) have momentum and so impart 
momentum onto things that they hit.

His second sentence I don't know anything about, so I can neither confirm 
nor deny it.
comments.author: Meg Ashley

comments.text:
everything has an escape velocity e.g. the earth.but with the mass and the 
size of the little very compacted star the escape velocity skyrockets 
meaning even light cant escape from its path. on the other hand there are 
black holes such as quasars  (cant spell) which emmits almost all the light 
it collects into two beams on each of its "poles" which have a weak spot 
where all the light can escape. WHY IS SPACE SO DANGEROUS
comments.author: euan todd

comments.text:
Light has energy, and since E=MC^2, energy is effectively mass, therefore 
gravity can alter the path of light because light effectively has mass.

Secondly, under some circumstances (which are beyond my realm of 
knowledge), photons can have mass (<1x10^-18 eV).
comments.author: TheMohawkNinja

comments.text:
+zemerick13 then there is also the atmosphere itself creates amounts of 
interference, and can actually bend light paths deflecting them from water 
vapors in the atmosphere etc (thats why some astronomers use things like a 
laser pointed up and measuring the reflected path to ascertain the amount 
of 'fix' needed to be applied for their telescope setups) so yeah i realize 
technically there are very real limits. all that and i still don't find it 
that surprising that a large beaver dam can be photographed from space :) 
-- even though i bet if they didnt know what it was already they wouldnt 
have enough resolution in that shot to tell it was a beaver dam!
comments.author: quosmo1

comments.text: +quosmo1 I'm sorry but I lol'd when I read that.
comments.author: Bud Charles

comments.text:
+quosmo1 Actually, not really. Light has a size ( its wavelength ), and so 
there is a maximum you could ever hope to magnify an image at a given 
wavelength. Visual light is big enough that it quickly becomes an issue. 
It's the same reason you can't get a microscope to look at a virus: That's 
beyond the maximum magnification.

That being said, we're talking about somewhere in the 5-20cm range based 
off of a lot of variables. ( Orbit of the satellite, weather/seeing 
conditions, size of the satellite, etc. ) So, an 850m would indeed be 
clearly visible.

Oh, just a follow up though: Most detailed images you see, for example 
those of Google Maps ( but this also applies to government agencies ), are 
from planes not satellites. One of the biggest factors is distance from the 
target, for obvious reasons. So, a plane flying at 3,000 feet gets an 
immensely better image than a satellite at more than a hundred times that. 
Satellites are for monitoring an area. If you see something interesting, 
you send in a plane. Still looks interesting, send someone in on ground:)

captions.text:
They're one of the largest rodents in the
world, they're indisputably adorable, and

hey, Canada doesn't put just anyone on their
money.

But the main reason you should appreciate
beavers is that they're second only to us

in their ability to completely transform the
environments they live in.
Usually for the better, though.

While we like to surround ourselves with warehouse
stores and hamburger restaurants, beavers

will turn a stream-fed meadow -- even a patch
of desert -- into a lush, watery habitat for

all sorts of wildlife, aquatic and land-lubber
alike.

They do it, of course, by building dams. And
darn, can these guys dam.

Most beaver dams are 5 to 10 meters long and
form small ponds behind them. But sometimes

these structures have been known to turn into
decades-long development projects.

The biggest beaver dam in the world, in Canada's
Wood Buffalo National Park, is more than 850

meters long, forming a huge wetland that's
actually been photographed from space.

It's been under construction since the 1970s,
with subsequent generations of beavers adding
to it, and it's getting bigger every year.

Beavers go through all the trouble of dam-building
primarily for defense. Some build lodges made

of sticks and mud in the ponds that they create,
while others burrow into their muddy banks.

Both are designed to be entered only underwater.
By surrounding themselves with deep water,

beavers can protect their dens from predators
like wolves and wild cats, while creating

a habitat that supports the aquatic plants
they like most, like cattails, willows, pondweed
and aspen.

The dams are usually started by single males
trying to attract a mate, or a young couple,
which pair up for life.
Adorable beaver love.

But one thing that's a little less cute is
how completely serious these guys are about

their dams. Scientists call it instinctive
behavior, but it can end up looking kind of
compulsive.

Biologists believe that the sound of running
water actually triggers dam-building behavior

in beavers. Some theorize that beavers may
even be able to feel, or otherwise sense in
the water, when a leak has sprung in a dam.

Research has shown that little gaps intentionally
created in a beaver dam will cause the members

of a colony to drop everything to repair it,
regardless of whatever else needs to be done.

Scientists — a little evil — have even
played audio recordings of running water near

beaver sites, and have returned in the morning
to find the speakers covered with sticks and
mud.

This obsessive engineering is all made possible
by beavers' trademark teeth. And you may have

heard that their teeth continue grow throughout
their lifetimes, which is true -- but only
their big, curved front incisors.

Beavers' voluminous tree-gnawing keeps their
teeth from growing too long, but they don't

actually eat through trees. They actually
prefer to feast on non-woody plants, like

water lilies and cattails, in the spring.
In winter, they strip trees of their bark

and the layer of soft tissue underneath known
as cambium.

And, despite what cartoons have taught us,
beavers' famous front teeth aren't white,

they're ORANGE because their tooth enamel
contains iron, which makes them incredibly

strong and sharp -- even though it makes them
look like they have a two-pack-a-day habit.
And finally, a note about beaver butts.
They smell DELIGHTFUL!

Both male and female beavers have a pair of
anal scent glands that they use to mark their

territory. And the yellowish oil that they
produce, called castoreum, smells precisely
like sweetened vanilla ...

... so much so that for hundreds of years
it was used to flavor food and drinks and,

in some places, can still be found in perfumes
and processed foods under the ambiguous moniker
of "natural flavoring."

Other cultures have prized castoreum for its
medicinal properties. And that might be because

one of beavers' favorite snacks is the bark
of willow trees, which contains the chemical

salicin, which people have used for centuries
to make natural pain-killers. But because

beavers eat so much of the bark, their sweet-smelling
butt-oils can be chock full of salicylic acid,
which is the precursor compound to aspirin.

Now -- what other animal can you think of
that makes its habitat more livable, drops

everything to keep its neighborhood safe,
and has a bum that smells like dessert?
I can't come up with anything.

Thanks for watching this SciShow Dose! If
you'd like to learn more about all kinds of

animals, check out our partner channel Animal
Wonders at YouTube.com/AnimalWondersMontana;
there's a link in the description.

And don't forget to go to YouTube.com/SciShow
to subscribe so you can keep on getting' smarter!
